description:
In Liechtenstein, as of March 16, all schools, educational and childcare establishments will be shut down.
On April 30 the gov of Liechtenstein announced that schools, educational and childcare establishments are going to reopen on May 11 under age-appropriate conditions. description: On May 4, the gov of Liechtenstein announced the framework under which schools, educational and childcare institutions are going to reopen from 11 May on. This encompasses age-appropriate hygiene measures and a combination of in-person and remote instructions for classes above class 5. In addition to this, classes are split into small groups.

description:
On May 4, the gov of Liechtenstein announced the framework under which schools, educational and childcare institutions are going to reopen from 11 May on. This encompasses age-appropriate hygiene measures and a combination of in-person and remote instructions for classes above class 5. In addition to this, classes are split into small groups.
On June 2, the gov of Liechtenstein announced that from June 8 on, in-person instructions are the new normal for all grades. In addition to this, classes aren't split up in groups anymore but taught together. UPDATE: On June 2, the gov of Liechtenstein announced that from June 8 on, in-person instructions are the new normal for all grades. In addition to this, classes aren't split up in groups anymore but taught together.

description: On June 2, the gov of Liechtenstein announced the further relaxation of measures concerning schools and other educational institutions. However, some restrictions prevail. While in-person instructions are the standard, pupils at higher risk are allowed to use remote instructions. Mixtures of classes shall be avoided and school events and parent's evenings are prohibited. While sports classes are allowed, high-contact forms of sport shall be avoided and swim classes prohibited. Hygiene measurements are maintained.
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
school_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions

description: On March 13th 2020, the Swiss Federal Council re-opens federal border checks including Schengen checks, designed to limit incoming and outgoing traffic to Italy. As Switzerland is in charge for border control of the Liechtenstein border, this applies also for the border of Liechtenstein to Austria. Only Swiss and Liechtenstein citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland or Liechtenstein and people who have to travel to Switzerland or Liechtenstein for professional reasons are allowed to enter. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from.
type_sub_cat: Visa extensions (e.g. visa validity extended)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On March 16th 2020, the Swiss Federal Council votes to extend border checks from Italy to France, Austria and Germany. As Switzerland is in charge for border control of the Liechtenstein border, this applies also for the border of Liechtenstein to Austria. Only Swiss and Liechtenstein citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland or Liechtenstein and people who have to travel to Switzerland or Liechtenstein for professional reasons are allowed to enter. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from.
type_sub_cat: Visa extensions (e.g. visa validity extended)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: The Swiss Federal Council extends entry restrictions/border checks to include all Schengen states and non-Schengen states except for the principality of Lichtenstein on March 25th 2020. As Switzerland is in charge for border control of the Liechtenstein border, this applies also for the border of Liechtenstein. The previous policy only applied to entrants from Italy, France, Germany and Austria.
type_sub_cat: Visa extensions (e.g. visa validity extended)

description:
On March 16th 2020, the Swiss Federal Council votes to extend border checks from Italy to France, Austria and Germany. As Switzerland is in charge for border control of the Liechtenstein border, this applies also for the border of Liechtenstein to Austria. Only Swiss and Liechtenstein citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland or Liechtenstein and people who have to travel to Switzerland or Liechtenstein for professional reasons are allowed to enter. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from.
On March 25th, this was extended to entry restrictions concerning all Schengen states and non-Schengen states. UPDATE: Initially, border restrictions only applied on Italy, France, Germany and Austria. On March 25th, the Swiss Federal Council extends entry restrictions/border checks to include all Schengen states and non-Schengen states. As Switzerland is in charge for border control of the Liechtenstein border, this applies also for the border of Liechtenstein.
type_sub_cat: Visa extensions (e.g. visa validity extended)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
The Swiss Federal Council extends entry restrictions/border checks to include all Schengen states and non-Schengen states except for the principality of Lichtenstein on March 25th 2020. As Switzerland is in charge for border control of the Liechtenstein border, this applies also for the border of Liechtenstein. The previous policy only applied to entrants from Italy, France, Germany and Austria.
On May 14th, the Government of Liechtenstein announced that from June 15th on, the border to Austria will be open again as usual.
 UPDATE: On May 15th, the government of Liechtenstein announced that from June 15th on, the border to Austria will be open again as usual.
type_sub_cat: Visa extensions (e.g. visa validity extended)

description: On March 14, Liechtenstein ordered skiers coming home from abroad to observe their health carefully.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: As of April 15, 2020, Liechtenstein announced new research and measures into better surveillance and monitoring of the spread of the coronavirus. This includes a pilot research project using elderly wrist bands for early covid-19 detection as well as monitoring waste water.
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 29 the gov of Liechtenstein publicly recommended to use the SwissCovidApp - programmed and used in Switzerland - for the improvement of contact tracing. The installation of the app is voluntarily.

description: From March 23, 2020, Liechtenstein announces to increase hospital capacities by postponing non-essential surgeries and adding capacities at hospitals and implements drive-through testing.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 24, the government of Liechtenstein recommended to store up to 50 face masks per individual for a potential second wave.

description: On February 11, 2020, Liechtenstein "set up a "new coronavirus 2019-nCoV" staff, which, under the chairmanship of the government councilor Mauro Pedrazzini, will monitor developments related to the new coronavirus and coordinate necessary measures for Liechtenstein."

description: On May 5, 2020, Liechtenstein announced a public awareness campaign targeting schools. The campaign will be called #HebenSorg. Posters and flyers explaining the most important hygiene measures to students. The campaign also extends to social media and the government websites as well as to question panel with the education minister allowing students to ask questions.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On May 12, Liechtenstein announced that on May 13, the government will publicly inform about the current situation and outline further steps.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On July 3 the gov of Liechtenstein announced that a 10-day quarantine will be imposed on all travelers who has been in a country of risk in the preceding 14 days, starting on July 6. The list is initiated and updated by the Swiss Federal Office of Public Health (FOPH) and currently encompasses Argentina, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Belarus, Bolivia, Brazil, Cape Verde, Chile, Dominican Republic, Honduras, Iraq, Israel, Qatar, Columbia, Kosovo, Kuwait, Republic of Moldova, Republic of North Macedonia, Oman, Panama, Peru, Russia, Saudi-Arabia, Sweden, Serbia, South Africa, Turks and Caicos Islands as well as the USA.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On July 23, the Federal Office of Public Health of Switzerland updated the list of high risks countries which the government of Liechtenstein adopts. People having been in the countries in the preceding 14 days have to go into 10-day quarantine. The initial policy started on July 6. The list currently encompasses Argentina, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Bolivia, Bosnien und Herzegovina, Brazil, Cape Verde, Chile, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Eswatini/Swasiland, Guatemala, Honduras, Iraq, Israel, Qatar, Columbia, Kazakhstan, Kosovo, Kuwait, Kyrgyzstan, Luxembourg, Maldives, Mexico, Republic of Moldova, Montenegro, Palestine, Republic of North Macedonia, Oman, Panama, Peru, Russia, Saudi-Arabia, Serbia, South Africa, Suriname, Turks and Caicos Islands, UAE as well as the USA.

description: In Liechtenstein, as of March 16, 2020, the following measures are in effect: Public and private museums, libraries, courses and educational training workshops, casinos, sports centers, fitness centers, gyms, wellness centers, youth centers, public baths, and the cable railway Malbun will be closed. As of May 15, museums, libraries and archives are allowed to open again with respective protective measures. Events are still prohibited. On April 30, the gov announced to suspend this measure on May 15 under the condition of provisions. description:
On March 13, 2020, Liechtenstein restricted events and gathering to a maximum of 100 people until at least the August 31, 2020 UPDATE: The restriction is extended to the April 30, 2020, and increased to only allow events of a maximum of 100 people, instead of the prior 1000.
The restriction is once again extended to the end of August 2020.

description:
On February 28, 2020, Liechtenstein restricted events and gathers to a maximum of 1,000 people until at least the 15th of March. 
On March 13, 2020, the level was set to a maximum of 100 people until at least the April 30, 2020.
On April 30, the restriction was extended to at least "end of August". UPDATE: Originally, the restriction of events and gathering to a maximum of 100 people was set to at least end of April, it has been extended to "at least end of August"
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On May 20, the government of Liechtenstein announced to replace the previous ban of gatherings of more than 5 people in public by an obligatory distance of 2m between people of different households. However, private and public events remain prohibited.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description:
On March 16, 2020, Liechtenstein further prohibits private and public events and gatherings of more than 5 people.
On May 20, the government of Liechtenstein announced to replace the previous ban of gatherings of more than 5 people in public by an obligatory distance of 2m between people of different households. However, private and public events remain prohibited. UPDATE: On May 20, the government of Liechtenstein announced to replace the previous ban of gatherings of more than 5 people in public by an obligatory distance of 2m between people of different households. However, private and public events remain prohibited.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On May 29, the gov of Liechtenstein announced that from June 6 on, private and public events can take place for up to 300 participants. Public events must provide a protection concept.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On May 29, the government of Liechtenstein announced that all cultural institutions still closed are allowed to reopen. However, night clubs are restricted to 100 people.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description:
On May 20, the government of Liechtenstein announced to replace the previous ban of gatherings of more than 5 people in public by an obligatory distance of 2m between people of different households. However, private and public events remain prohibited.

description:
On May 29, the gov of Liechtenstein announced that from June 6 on, private and public events can take place for up to 300 participants. Public events must provide a protection concept.
On June 24 the gov of Liechtenstein announced that events are only restricted to 1.000 participants from July 3 on. Events with more than 1000 participants will presumably be possible from September on. UPDATE: On June 24 the gov of Liechtenstein announced that events are only restricted to 1.000 participants from July 3 on.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description:
On February 28, 2020, Liechtenstein restricted events and gathers to a maximum of 1,000 people until at least the 15th of March.
On March 13, 2020, the level was set to a maximum of 100 people until at least the April 30, 2020.
On April 30, the restriction was extended to at least "end of August".
On August 18, the restriction was extended to the end of September. UPDATE: On August 18, the restriction was extended to the end of September.

description: On May 18, the government of Liechtenstein published a press release to "strongly recommend" wearing a mask in public transport. On July 3, the gov of Liechtenstein announced that masks are obligatory in public transport from July 6 on. UPDATE: On July 3, the gov of Liechtenstein announced that masks are obligatory in public transport from July 6 on. Before, it was only recommended to wear masks.
